title: June 2017 FQE - Paper 1 (Clinical Essays)
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine and Surgery - Paediatrics Paper 1 (June 2017). Covers Clinical Scenario Questions and Long Essays.

questions.question: A 6-day-old baby born at home presents with fever, refusal to breastfeed, irritability, and an inflamed umbilical stump with discharge. Select the correct diagnosis and management steps.

richContent.content:
Clinical Case:
6-day-old, home delivery.
Symptoms: Fever (37.9°C), Irritability, Refusal to feed.
Signs: Inflamed umbilical stump, discharge.

questions.explanation: This is Neonatal Sepsis secondary to Omphalitis. Key steps: Admit, Septic screen (Blood culture, CBC, RBS), and start IV Antibiotics (Ampicillin + Gentamicin). Oral treatment is inadequate for systemic neonatal sepsis.
questions.hint: Infection of the umbilical cord spreading systemically.

questions.question: Regarding breastfeeding, select the correct advantages and signs of good attachment.

options.text: Advantage: Promotes uterine involution in mother
Sign: More areola visible above the mouth than below

questions.explanation: Good attachment signs: Mouth wide open, Lower lip turned OUTWARDS, Chin touching breast, More areola above. Benefits include immunity, nutrition, bonding, and maternal health.

questions.question: A 4-year-old presents with fever, acidotic breathing, and prostration after visiting Kisumu. What is the most probable diagnosis and first-line IV treatment?
questions.explanation: History of travel to endemic area (Kisumu) + Fever + Acidotic breathing + Prostration = Severe Malaria. IV Artesunate is the gold standard.

questions.question: A 2-year-old has cough, difficulty breathing, grunting, and chest indrawing. Select the correct diagnosis and management.
questions.explanation: Grunting and Chest Indrawing indicate Severe Pneumonia requiring admission, oxygen, and IV antibiotics. Nebulization is for asthma/wheeze, not primary pneumonia treatment.

questions.question: A 3-year-old with diarrhea has sunken eyes, sunken fontanel, and drinks poorly. What is the correct fluid management plan?

options.text: Plan A: Home fluids and Zinc

questions.explanation: The child has signs of Severe Dehydration (Sunken eyes, Drinking poorly/unable). This requires Plan C: Immediate IV fluids (RL/NS).

questions.question: A 2-year-old presents with generalized tonic-clonic convulsions and fever of 39°C. This is the 4th episode (previous one 7 months ago). Select the likely diagnosis and investigations.

options.text: Investigation: Lumbar Puncture (to rule out meningitis)

questions.explanation: Recurrent convulsions with fever in this age group suggests Complex Febrile Seizures. LP is crucial to rule out meningitis. Malaria treatment is only if slide is positive (history says no travel, but testing is still valid; however, 'Complex Febrile Convulsion' is the specific syndromic diagnosis requested).

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents with migratory joint pain, jerky movements, fever, and a macular rash on the trunk. Select the correct diagnosis and Jones criteria present.
questions.explanation: The child exhibits 3 Major Jones Criteria: Polyarthritis, Chorea, and Erythema Marginatum. Diagnosis is Acute Rheumatic Fever.

questions.question: Peter (12y, 30kg) has Sickle Cell Disease and presents with severe bone pain, fever, and pallor. Select the correct management steps for his Painful Crisis.

options.text: Apply ice packs to painful areas

questions.explanation: Standard crisis management involves Aggressive Hydration, Analgesia, and Oxygen. Cold/Ice is contraindicated as it promotes sickling.

questions.question: A 5-year-old presents with puffiness of the face (worse in morning), tea-colored urine, and BP 140/100 mmHg. History of sore throat 3 weeks ago. Select the correct diagnosis and management.
questions.explanation: This is Nephritic Syndrome (APSGN). Key management: Fluid/Salt restriction, BP control, and antibiotics. High fluid/protein intake worsens the condition.
